author: By Michael D. Shear
title: The White House will continue to impose travel bans, citing Delta variant concerns.
description: “The more transmissible Delta variant is spreading both here and around the world,” the White House press secretary said, and cases are rising.
content: The Biden administration will continue to restrict the entry of Europeans and others into the United States, citing concerns that infected travelers may contribute to further spread of the contagious Delta variant across the country, Jen Psaki, the White House press secretary, said Monday afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Ariarne Titmus defeats Katie Ledecky in the 400-meter freestyle.
description: Results from the women’s 400-meter freestyle.
content: In one of the most anticipated showdowns of the Tokyo Games, Ariarne Titmus of Australia defeated Katie Ledecky of the United States in the 400-meter freestyle, beating the reigning champion by two-thirds of a second.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Lebanon Turns to Billionaire Tycoon to Form Next Government
description: Najib Mikati, who has served as prime minister twice before, will try to form a government that can please Lebanon’s politicians and address its financial meltdown. His two predecessors failed.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A billionaire telecoms tycoon, Najib Mikati, was appointed Monday to form Lebanon’s next government, handing him the challenge of trying to pull the small Mediterranean country out of a downward economic spiral.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below in the introductory article for this feature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: California’s largest wildfire is burning near scarred communities.
description: The Dixie Fire started near the same spot as the deadly 2018 Camp Fire. “One of the most concerning things about it is how early in the year it is,” a fire official said.
content: The Dixie Fire, California’s largest wildfire this year, continued to chew through thousands of acres of rough terrain on Monday, prompting evacuation orders and threatening communities in a region scarred by the memory of the 2018 Camp Fire, the deadliest in the state’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Breakthrough Covid, in Perspective
description: We offer advice about how to think about the cases.
content: Breakthrough infections — in which vaccinated people nonetheless get the Covid-19 virus — are one of those vexing topics that can be difficult to put in perspective.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Ice Buckets
description: Do you really need an ice bucket? Only if you don’t want to keep running to the freezer for ice.
content: If you’re mixing cocktails for friends and don’t want to keep going to the freezer for ice, an ice bucket is essential.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Loh Prasad
title: Marking a Pandemic, One Crane at a Time
description: My son and I took on what seemed like a simple project: fold one origami crane every day during the pandemic. Together, we discovered over the year how making art helps people bear the unbearable.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — On March 5, 2020, my family attended our sixth grader’s school music performance, then went straight to dinner and a concert at Yoshi’s, a local jazz club, to celebrate my husband’s birthday. We didn’t know at the time it would be our last family outing for more than a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Tesla reports a big jump in profit.
description: The electric car company made $1 billion in the second quarter as its revenue roughly doubled from the same period a year earlier.
content: Tesla on Monday reported a big increase in profit for the three months ending in June because it sold more than twice as many cars in the period as it did a year earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: A Runner’s Olympic Dream Was in Doubt Because of His DACA Status
description: Luis Grijalva, who qualified to run for his native Guatemala, risked not being able to return to the United States if he left. On Monday, he got good news.
content: When Luis Grijalva crossed the finish line second in the 5,000-meter race at the N.C.A.A. track and field championship meet last month, he had plenty to celebrate: a new personal best time, a national record in his native Guatemala and a ticket to the Olympic Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: A gnarly brown Christmas? Tree farms dry out in the Pacific Northwest.
description: Wildfires and drought are reducing Oregon’s Christmas tree harvest, and driving up prices.
content: When Jacob Hemphill pulled into the driveway at his 200-acre Christmas tree farm in Oregon City, Ore., on the second night of a record-breaking heat wave late last month, his stomach dropped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: After the pandemic halted their momentum, America’s rugby sevens teams are eager for a medal.
description: CHULA VISTA, Calif. — The American men’s and women’s rugby sevens teams know something about momentum in sports. It’s a funny thing, because it can crystallize seemingly out of nowhere and vanish just as easily.
content: CHULA VISTA, Calif. — The American men’s and women’s rugby sevens teams know something about momentum in sports. It’s a funny thing, because it can crystallize seemingly out of nowhere and vanish just as easily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Two insurance giants call off their planned merger after a Justice Dept. lawsuit.
description: The department’s case against the proposed merger of Aon and Willis Towers Watson was the first big trustbusting move by the Biden administration.
content: Two of the world’s largest insurance brokers, Aon and Willis Towers Watson, announced on Monday that they had called off a planned $30 billion merger, just a little more than a month after the Department of Justice sued to block the union.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing and Matthew Goldstein
title: Lordstown Motors, a troubled electric truck start-up, raises up to $400 million.
description: The deal would provide badly needed cash to a company that said this summer that it could go out of business without raising more money.
content: Lordstown Motors, a struggling electric pickup truck company, said Monday that it had reached a deal with an investment firm to raise $400 million over three years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh
title: Scores Die in India as Monsoon Rains Swamp Towns and Send Boulders Tumbling
description: Every monsoon season poses risks to the country, but this one is shaping up as especially destructive as climate change turbocharges rainfall.
content: NEW DELHI — Within seconds, the scenic mountain valley resembled a war zone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: The N.B.A. Draft and Cesar Millan
description: The N.B.A. hosts its 75th draft and Cesar Millan returns to TV with a new show focused on rescue dogs and their owners.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, July 26-Aug. 1. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Young skateboarders dominate to advance to the women’s street finals.
description: TOKYO — The women took the stage in skateboarding on Monday at Ariake Urban Sports Park, where the women’s street final presents several intriguing possibilities. They mostly revolve around Japan, and the chance that a 13-year-old Brazilian could win a gold medal.
content: TOKYO — The women took the stage in skateboarding on Monday at Ariake Urban Sports Park, where the women’s street final presents several intriguing possibilities. They mostly revolve around Japan, and the chance that a 13-year-old Brazilian could win a gold medal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Caeleb Dressel leads the U.S. to victory in the 4x100-meter freestyle relay.
description: Results from the men’s 4x100-meter freestyle relay.
content: The United States prevailed in the 4x100-meter freestyle relay Monday, topping Italy with the third fastest relay in history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: France approves a contentious law making health passes mandatory.
description: The vote came after days of heated parliamentary debates and protests against the measure in dozens of French cities.
content: France passed a new Covid-19 law late on Sunday that makes health passes mandatory for a number of indoor venues as the country faces a fourth wave of infections. The vote came after days of heated parliamentary debates that lasted long into the night and protests against the measure in dozens of French cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
title: At the F.D.A.’s urging, Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna are expanding their trials for children 5 to 11.
description: It was unclear whether expanding the studies will have any impact on the timing of when vaccines could be authorized for children on an emergency basis.
content: At the urging of federal regulators, two coronavirus vaccine makers are expanding the size of their clinical trials for children ages 5 to 11 — a precautionary measure designed to detect rare side effects including heart inflammation problems that turned up in vaccinated people younger than 30.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Zavitsanos
title: We’re Kidding Ourselves That Workers Perform Well From Home
description: My office reopened at the height of the pandemic. We’ve thrived.
content: HOUSTON — This March, my partners and I paid special bonuses to all employees at my law firm in the heart of this city. Unlike at many other firms around the country, this $395,000 in bonuses — in addition to the $2.7 million in year-end bonuses — was not some apology or atonement for cutbacks stemming from the coronavirus economy. We wanted to reward all 90 of our employees for their record-breaking work in 2020: Our small, specialized, 28-year-old firm had its best year yet, and we did it mostly together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dawn Perry
title: No-Roll Pie Crusts for Simple Summer Desserts
description: The perfect pies for lazy days combine buttery press-in crumb shells with no-bake fillings and piles of fresh fruit.
content: The allure of a homemade fruit pie is real: Just imagine a bubbling double-crusted blueberry number cooling by a breezy window. But the prospect of rolling dough on a steamy day can send even confident cooks packing. To turn out stellar pies showcasing summer’s ripest fruit — without heating up the kitchen — you want the ease of crumb crusts and chilled fillings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Return to Office Hits a Snag: Young Resisters
description: A generation gap has emerged between them and colleagues who value the workplace over the advantages of remote work. Bridging it may require flexibility.
content: David Gross, an executive at a New York-based advertising agency, convened the troops over Zoom this month to deliver a message he and his fellow partners were eager to share: It was time to think about coming back to the office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Katie Ledecky Feels the Sting of a First Olympic Loss
description: In the 400-meter freestyle, she was something of an underdog. But she had never lost at the Olympics until Monday.
content: TOKYO — The moment Katie Ledecky knew would eventually come, though maybe not this soon, happened three-quarters of the way through the 400-meter freestyle Monday morning at the Tokyo Aquatics Centre.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons, Shawn Hubler and Jennifer Steinhauer
title: New York City and California to Require Vaccines or Tests for Workers
description: California and New York City announced the mandates for their employees, while the Department of Veterans Affairs said frontline health care workers must get vaccinated or face possible termination.
content: The push to mandate coronavirus vaccinations amid sharply rising caseloads nationwide accelerated on Monday, as the country’s most populous state and its largest city both announced that they would require hundreds of thousands of government workers to get inoculations or face weekly testing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Berger
title: Rabbi Yoel Kahn, Oral Scribe for the Grand Rabbi, Dies at 91
description: For decades he memorized virtually verbatim the speeches and discourses of Rabbi Menachem Schneerson and meticulously compiled them into about 150 volumes.
content: Rabbi Yoel Kahn, who as a leading disciple of Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson, the revered leader of the Lubavitch Hasidim, had the uncanny ability to memorize virtually verbatim the grand rabbi’s hourslong speeches and discourses, which he then compiled into roughly 150 published volumes, died on July 15 in Manhattan. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Nancy Pelosi Is Working in a World Where the Other Side Won’t Play Fair
description: How did the Jan. 6 investigation become such a political football?
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I don’t think there’s much doubt among reasonably sane people about what happened at the Capitol on Jan. 6. Do we really need a House committee to investigate it?
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: July 26, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, July 26, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ned Resnikoff
title: It’s Hard to Have Faith in a State That Can’t Even House Its People
description: Homelessness is both a symptom and a cause of the growing political crisis.
content: Even if you don’t live in California, you’ve probably seen the pictures of tents lining Venice Beach. Or maybe you’ve seen photographs of Oakland’s sprawling homeless encampments, or the crowds of people living on the street in Los Angeles’s Skid Row neighborhood. Those images, while stark, do not come close to capturing the scope of the state’s homelessness crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon
title: Vaccines, Olympics, Tunisia: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: Wildfires Ravage Sardinia in ‘a Disaster Without Precedent’
description: A 25-mile swath of vegetation, farms and villages is hit by one of the largest wildfires in decades, devastating the Italian tourist destination.
content: About 1,000 residents and tourists have been evacuated from areas of western Sardinia that were ravaged by wildfires over the weekend, with forests, pastures and villages on the Italian island engulfed in flames.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Return of the Family Values Zombie
description: Children need real help, not empty rhetoric.
content: For a few weeks in 1992, U.S. politics were all about “family values.” President George H.W. Bush was in electoral trouble because of a weak economy and rising inequality. So his vice president, Dan Quayle, tried to change the subject by attacking Murphy Brown, a character in a TV sitcom, an unmarried woman who chose to have a child.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: New Charcuterie Straight From Olympia Provisions
description: The Portland, Ore., company has a new collection using meat from small family farms.
content: Olympia Provisions in Portland, Ore., a company that specializes in European-style charcuterie, has started spinning out a new salami collection, called Farmers Network, using meat from small family farms in Oregon. Their first release is Rosette d’Oregon, based on the classic dry French sausage called Rosette de Lyon and made with pasture-raised heritage pork, Willamette Valley pinot noir and herbs. It’s a slender, meaty sausage, on the chewy side and cured with a thin natural casing that’s easily removed for slicing and serving alongside glasses of a cool red.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo
title: As Cyberattacks Surge, Security Start-Ups Reap the Rewards
description: Investors have poured $12.2 billion into cybersecurity companies so far this year, nearly $2 billion more than the total for all of 2020.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — As cyberattacks proliferated this year, Sanjay Beri, the chief executive of Netskope, a cloud security start-up, got a phone call. Then an email. Then more messages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Rep. Clay Higgins, a staunch opponent of mask mandates, announces he and his family have Covid-19.
description: Mr. Higgins, an outspoken coronavirus skeptic who has drafted a bill to make vaccine mandates a federal crime, made the announcement on Facebook over the weekend.
content: Representative Clay Higgins, Republican of Louisiana and an outspoken coronavirus skeptic who has drafted legislation to make vaccine mandates a federal crime, announced this weekend that he, his wife and his son have Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: The Extraordinary History (and Likely Busy Future) of Quarantine
description: “Until Proven Safe,” by Geoff Manaugh and Nicola Twilley, is about the lifesaving measure that has also been abused for political purposes over the centuries.
content: Quarantine can be lifesaving; it can also be dangerous, an exercise of extraordinary power in the name of disease control, a presumption of guilt instead of innocence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: The Most Dominant Team at the Games Might Be Better Than Ever
description: The U.S. women’s water polo team won Olympic championships in London and Rio. A one-year delay of the Tokyo Games merely gave it more time to improve.
content: TOKYO — There is never a shortage of strong American teams heading to the Olympics. The women’s basketball team has won six consecutive gold medals, and the men’s team three in a row. The larger-than-life personalities on the World Cup-winning women’s soccer team have captured the news media spotlight, and the women’s gymnastics team, led by Simone Biles, is a heavy favorite in Tokyo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: Wildfires ravage the Italian island of Sardinia in ‘a disaster without precedent.’
description: About 1,000 residents and tourists have been evacuated from areas of western Sardinia that were ravaged by wildfires over the weekend, with forests, pastures and villages on the Italian island engulfed in flames.
content: About 1,000 residents and tourists have been evacuated from areas of western Sardinia that were ravaged by wildfires over the weekend, with forests, pastures and villages on the Italian island engulfed in flames.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli, Liz Day and Samantha Stark
title: Britney Spears Files to Remove Her Father From Conservatorship
description: More than 13 years after a strict legal arrangement gave James P. Spears control of the singer’s affairs, a new lawyer for Ms. Spears asked the court to remove him from the arrangement.
content: More than 13 years after the life and finances of Britney Spears were put under the strict, court-approved control of her father, James P. Spears — and a month after Ms. Spears broke her public silence on the arrangement, calling it abusive and singling him out as its ultimate authority — a new lawyer for the singer has moved to have Mr. Spears removed from the unique conservatorship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Lingering tensions in Nagorno-Karabakh.
content: The Tokyo Games opened on Friday to a sea of empty seats and a somber opening ceremony that tried to project a world moving on from the worst of Covid-19. Naomi Osaka, Japan’s most famous athlete, lit the Olympic cauldron.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annabelle Williams
title: Sally Miller Gearhart, Lesbian Writer and Activist, Dies at 90
description: She fought anti-gay policies alongside Harvey Milk, wrote influential books, including science fiction, and founded a women-only refuge in the woods.
content: Sally Miller Gearhart, a feminist, lesbian activist and prominent opponent of anti-gay policies whose writings included a classic of lesbian science fiction about a women-only society, much like the one she later founded in Northern California, died on July 14 in Ukiah, Calif. She was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Thomas
title: Scenes From a Dude Ranch on the High Plains
description: For more than 10 years, a British photographer spent her summers at a dude ranch in northwest Wyoming. Here’s what she captured.
content: My horse was ready to bolt — his ears pricked, his muscles tense. A few feet ahead, a herd of wild horses stared back at us; they’d been unaware of us for most of our ascent from the valley below. Horned lizards shuffled in the sagebrush beneath us, but my horse’s gaze remained locked on his untamed brethren.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Momiji Nishiya, 13, grabbed gold in street skateboarding as part of the sport’s youthful surge.
description: Nishiya, of Japan, is among the youngest athletes at the Tokyo Games.
content: TOKYO — Youth was served to a global audience on Monday when two 13-year-old skateboarders fought to the final trick to determine the winner of the women’s street competition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Why Top Democrats Are Listening to Eric Adams Right Now
description: Some prominent Democrats think their party’s nominee for mayor of New York offers a template for how to address issues of public safety.
content: When Eric Adams won New York City’s Democratic mayoral primary, his supporters in Congress were bombarded with questions about him from colleagues representing districts in Michigan and Florida, Chicago and Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Cooking With the Abundance of Maine
description: “The Maine Farm Table Cookbook” includes recipes from restaurants, farms, dairies and more across the state.
content: The harvest of Maine’s farms, as presented in “The Maine Farm Table Cookbook,” is not dramatically different from that of many other states. (Consider a recipe for corn pancakes.) But then there’s Maine’s distinctive abundance of seafood and a trove of recipes: lush grilled halibut with spiced butter sauce and snow peas, and lobster rolls from Luke’s Lobster, the Maine-based company with restaurants in New York and across the globe. The brightly photographed book profiles the restaurants, farms, dairies, markets, breweries, bakeries and other food producers that have contributed recipes; they’re highlighted in the table of contents to make them easy to discover. Sara Jenkins, the owner of Nina June in Rockport and Porsena in Manhattan (now closed), provided one of the simplest and best recipes for eggplant Parmesan you’re likely to find. Come winter you might not have the means to prepare the moose Bourguignon, but venison would work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Eduardo Medina
title: 8 Are Killed as Sandstorm in Utah Causes a Highway Pileup
description: Officials said 22 vehicles were involved in a crash after high winds created a sandstorm that limited visibility on Interstate 15. Some of those killed were children, the highway patrol said.
content: At least eight people, some of them children, were killed and several others were injured when a sandstorm that blinded drivers led to a pileup in southwestern Utah, state officials said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: The forecast at the Olympics calls for strong winds and rain as a typhoon approaches.
description: The Summer Olympics in Tokyo have already been disrupted by a pandemic and sweltering heat. Starting on Tuesday, athletes and organizers will also have to deal with strong winds and heavy rain, with a typhoon expected to make landfall north of the city.
content: The Summer Olympics in Tokyo have already been disrupted by a pandemic and sweltering heat. Starting on Tuesday, athletes and organizers will also have to deal with strong winds and heavy rain, with a typhoon expected to make landfall north of the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: U.S. broadcast coverage on Monday night includes beach volleyball, swimming and basketball.
description: NBC will also air a replay of the men’s gymnastics team final.
content: Here are some highlights of U.S. broadcast coverage for Monday night, including women’s beach volleyball, women’s basketball and several swimming events. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Shunned by G.O.P., Cheney and Kinzinger Seek Answers on Jan. 6 Riot
description: They have been isolated and ostracized by their party for accepting Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s offer to sit on the special committee investigating the Capitol assault.
content: WASHINGTON — Outside the White House on Monday, the eve of the first hearing to investigate the Capitol riot, Representative Kevin McCarthy had an insult and a threat for the two members of his party daring to participate in the inquiry into how and why a pro-Trump mob attacked the Capitol on Jan. 6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Booker Prize Longlist Is Unveiled
description: Rachel Cusk’s “Second Place,” Richard Powers’s “Bewilderment” and Kazuo Ishiguro’s “Klara and the Sun” are among the 13 novels nominated for one of the world’s most prestigious literary awards.
content: LONDON — Kazuo Ishiguro, Rachel Cusk and Richard Powers are among the literary heavyweights in the running for the 2021 Booker Prize, it was announced here on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: American Ballet Theater’s Executive Director Announces Her Departure
description: Kara Medoff Barnett, who has held the post for the last five and a half years, will leave later this year.
content: American Ballet Theater was already looking for new leadership, with Kevin McKenzie, its artistic director of nearly three decades, planning to leave in 2022. Now, it must find new administrative leadership as well: Kara Medoff Barnett, its executive director, announced on Monday that she would be stepping down later this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Williamstown Theater Festival Tries to Weather the Storms
description: The annual summer festival in Massachusetts has tried to adapt amid the pandemic and calls for more diversity onstage.
content: I hate getting caught in the rain. But lately, with the mercurial weather and my new dog-walking schedule, I’ve found myself caught in bright sun showers, swampy mists and downright tempests. In my humble opinion, rain is nothing to sing about — Gene Kelly be damned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: How TV Went From David Brent to Ted Lasso
description: Two decades ago, TV’s most distinctive stories were defined by a tone of ironic detachment. Today, they’re more often sincere and direct. How did we get here?
content: Could David Brent get hired today?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Review: To a Rare King Arthur Opera, Bard Says ‘Welcome Back’
description: Superb singers and a clear production make a strong case for Ernest Chausson’s seldom heard “Le Roi Arthus.”
content: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — It took just two words over the loudspeakers for the audience at the Fisher Center for the Performing Arts at Bard College on Sunday evening to break into vigorous applause: “Welcome back.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: At Wagner’s Festival, a ‘Dutchman’ Never Sails
description: With neither ship nor sea, Dmitri Tcherniakov’s new Bayreuth Festival staging recasts the opera as a tale of violent revenge.
content: BAYREUTH, Germany — The pilgrims to the Green Hill, who have been making their way to the storied festival Richard Wagner founded here 145 years ago, looked more like cattle on Sunday. The theater’s bucolic grounds had become a network of roped-off, one-way sidewalks and checkpoints.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: Glossary of Spelling Bee Terms
description: How to become a Genius, and how to talk about it.
content: Thanks to reader Monicat for compiling this glossary of common terms people use when talking about the Spelling Bee:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Germany considers restrictions for unvaccinated adults.
description: BERLIN — The authorities in Germany are considering reinstating some restrictions for adults who are not vaccinated against Covid-19 if daily infections substantially increase in the coming months.
content: BERLIN — The authorities in Germany are considering reinstating some restrictions for adults who are not vaccinated against Covid-19 if daily infections substantially increase in the coming months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2 Million Homes in California
description: A storybook cottage in Los Angeles, a contemporary home in Long Beach and a Victorian in San Francisco.
content: This San Fernando Valley house is in Colfax Meadows, a quiet section of the Studio City neighborhood, which was named for the nearby movie lots established in the 1920s by Mack Sennett, the slapstick movie pioneer. Less than half a mile away is a popular stretch of Tujunga Avenue, where cafes are usually bustling with activity. Several schools are also close by, including Carpenter Community Charter School, a public elementary school, and Oakwood School, a private elementary, middle and high school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Why was Pacific Northwest heat off the charts? Recent research offers clues.
description: A study suggests that the world can expect more record-shattering heat waves in the future, unless drastic action is taken to curb climate change.
content: The ferocious heat wave that hit the Pacific Northwest in late June stunned some climate scientists because it was so much more extreme than anything the region had experienced before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rob Szypko, Rachel Quester, Stella Tan, Daniel Guillemette, Marion Lozano, Dave Shaw, Lisa Chow and Chris Wood
title: Breakthrough Infections, Explained
description: Why are a growing number of vaccinated Americans testing positive for the coronavirus?
content: For the past couple of weeks, some Americans have reported a curious phenomenon: They have caught the coronavirus despite being vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
title: Vaccine Makers Are Asked to Expand Safety Studies on Children
description: The F.D.A. wants Pfizer and Moderna to increase the number of 5- to 11-year-olds who participate in trials of their coronavirus vaccines to ensure there is enough data about rare side effects.
content: WASHINGTON — At the urging of federal regulators, two coronavirus vaccine makers are expanding the size of their studies in children ages 5 to 11 — a precautionary measure intended to detect rare side effects including heart inflammation problems that turned up in vaccinated people younger than 30.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: ‘Long Covid’ patients will be covered by federal disability law, Biden says.
description: People with persistent health problems from a coronavirus infection can qualify for benefits under the Americans With Disabilities Act, the president said on Monday.
content: Americans suffering from “long Covid” — a term referring to new or ongoing health problems from a coronavirus infection that occurred weeks or months ago — will have access to the benefits and protection provided under federal disability law, President Biden said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Russian Men Win Gymnastics Gold by the Slimmest of Margins
description: They stunned the host, Japan, which appeared poised to win. The U.S. men, who finished fifth, vowed to try more difficult routines in the future.
content: TOKYO — Nikita Nagornyy could barely keep it together on the medals podium on Monday night after Russia won the men’s gymnastics team event at the Tokyo Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: The E.P.A. will revise a Trump-era rule on toxic wastewater from coal plants.
description: The agency said the changes will prevent lead, selenium and other toxic pollutants from contaminating waterways.
content: The Biden administration will revise a Trump-era rule that allowed many coal-fired power plants to avoid or delay installing equipment that could prevent lead, selenium and other toxic pollutants from seeping into rivers and streams, the Environmental Protection Agency announced Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Thomas Barrack, a Trump ally and former fund-raiser, pleads not guilty to illegal lobbying charges.
description: Earlier this week, Mr. Barrack was released on $250 million bond and ordered to wear a GPS location-monitoring bracelet at all times, according to a Justice Department spokesman.
content: Thomas J. Barrack Jr., a billionaire private equity investor and close ally to former President Donald J. Trump, pleaded not guilty on Monday to charges of illegal lobbying for the United Arab Emirates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Harding
title: The World Needs a Heavy Hitter on the Pandemic. Bush Has Done It Before.
description: President Biden should enlist him as a special envoy.
content: The Biden administration says it wants to end the pandemic in 2022. If it’s serious about that goal, President Biden should relieve George W. Bush of his paintbrush and easel and draft him as America’s vaccine envoy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: The Messy Truth About Kids’ Screen Time
description: Absolute rules about children and technology don’t help, says a child development expert.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: ‘Dune’ and Princess Diana Biopic to Debut at a Starry Venice Film Festival
description: Hollywood blockbusters are back on the program after a less celebrity-driven edition last year, but the event will still be far from business as usual.
content: “Dune,” Denis Villeneuve’s highly anticipated science-fiction epic starring Timothée Chalamet, and Pablo Larraín’s “Spencer,” which dramatizes Princess Diana’s decision to divorce Prince Charles, are among the movies that will premiere at this year’s Venice Film Festival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Mandating vaccines
content: In the most drastic response yet to the lagging vaccination campaign and a Delta fueled surge in infections, a number of local and state governments in the U.S. announced that they were imposing vaccine mandates for workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo
title: QR Codes Are Here to Stay. So Is the Tracking They Allow.
description: Fueled by a desire for touchless transactions, QR codes popped up everywhere in the pandemic. Businesses don’t want to give them up.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — When people enter Teeth, a bar in San Francisco’s Mission neighborhood, the bouncer gives them options. They can order food and drinks at the bar, he says, or they can order via a QR code.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin and Shawn Hubler
title: California will require many health care workers, and all state employees, to get shots or tested regularly.
description: The move comes as officials across the country grapple with whether to mandate vaccinations to fight off coronavirus outbreaks.
content: California will require all state employees and on-site public and private health care workers to be vaccinated or face at least weekly testing, Gov. Gavin Newsom announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carla Correa
title: What to Watch in the Women’s Gymnastics Team Final
description: Simone Biles and Team U.S.A. must move past a mistake-laden qualifying round to edge out the surprising Russian team for gold.
content: The United States has reigned over women’s gymnastics for more than a decade, with the last team defeat handed to it by Russia in 2010, by only two-tenths of a point. Since then — and particularly with Simone Biles’s emergence on the world scene in 2013 — the American team has seemed unstoppable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Requests for U.S. college aid are down, with experts blaming the pandemic.
description: Many students who could qualify for help, who are disproportionately Black and Hispanic, seem to be responding to the economic uncertainties by taking newly abundant jobs.
content: U.S. high school seniors completed fewer federal financial aid applications for college this year, as compared with last year, which saw an even steeper drop — signals that the number of low-income students attending college is falling again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Why U.S. Basketball May Not Coast Through the Olympics
description: Although still favored to win a medal, the American team is paying a price for a lack of preparation and the global surge in the game.
content: TOKYO — The globalization of basketball has been well documented for decades. International tournaments are more competitive than ever. Elite talent sprouts up everywhere. Players from some national teams train together for half their lives, establishing a yearslong harmony that expresses itself on the court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: The team final arrives for women’s gymnastics on Tuesday, and U.S. women debut in basketball.
description: TOKYO — The United States women’s gymnastics team, and its transcendent star Simone Biles, showed feet of clay in the preliminaries, finishing behind Russia. The slate is wiped clean for Tuesday’s team final, but the unexpectedly shaky performance suddenly adds some drama to what some thought would be an easy coast to gold. The action starts at 7:45 p.m. Tokyo time, 6:45 a.m. Eastern. While the event can be streamed live on the Peacock service in the United States, NBC is expected to hold off the television broadcast until prime time.
content: TOKYO — The United States women’s gymnastics team, and its transcendent star Simone Biles, showed feet of clay in the preliminaries, finishing behind Russia. The slate is wiped clean for Tuesday’s team final, but the unexpectedly shaky performance suddenly adds some drama to what some thought would be an easy coast to gold. The action starts at 7:45 p.m. Tokyo time, 6:45 a.m. Eastern. While the event can be streamed live on the Peacock service in the United States, NBC is expected to hold off the television broadcast until prime time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward, Patricia Mazzei and Audra D. S. Burch
title: Final Victim of Surfside Condo Collapse Is Identified
description: A relative of Estelle Hedaya, 54, said the authorities had identified her remains. The final death toll is 98.
content: SURFSIDE, Fla. — More than a month after the terrifying collapse of a condominium tower in Surfside, Fla., the last victim’s remains were identified on Monday, bringing the final death toll to 98 and capping a tedious, painstaking effort to account for every resident who had been killed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Russia Is Banned, Yet It’s Everywhere at the Games
description: A doping punishment changes a country’s official name but little else about its Olympic experience.
content: TOKYO — For a country officially barred from the Olympics, Russia is very much a presence at this summer’s Tokyo Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Elliot Lawrence, Award-Winning Conductor, Dies at 96
description: He led a big band, conducted on Broadway, collected Emmys and for nearly 50 years led the orchestra on the annual Tony Awards broadcast.
content: Elliot Lawrence, who after leading a big band in the 1940s and ’50s won a Tony Award for his conducting on Broadway and spent nearly a half-century in charge of the orchestra that plays on the Tonys’ annual broadcast, died on July 2 in Manhattan. He was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Corporate America Rethinks Vaccine Mandates
description: New outbreaks have companies weighing their options.
content: Last month, Goldman Sachs unofficially kicked off Wall Street’s return to the office in a celebratory mood. (There were food trucks and live music). The tone has since changed, as the highly contagious Delta variant spreads and nearly half of the U.S. population isn’t fully vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers, Keith Bradsher and Chris Buckley
title: As China boomed, it didn’t take climate change into account. Now it must.
description: China’s breakneck growth over the last four decades erected soaring cities where there had been hamlets and farmland. The cities lured factories, and the factories lured workers. The boom lifted hundreds of millions of people out of the poverty and rural hardship they once faced.
content: China’s breakneck growth over the last four decades erected soaring cities where there had been hamlets and farmland. The cities lured factories, and the factories lured workers. The boom lifted hundreds of millions of people out of the poverty and rural hardship they once faced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: For Decades, Versailles Restaurant Has Been a Hub for Cuban Protests
description: The Miami restaurant’s long history for protesters and revelers continues, with recent demonstrations denouncing shortages of food and medicine in Cuba.
content: MIAMI — Outside Versailles Restaurant, on Calle Ocho, near Miami’s Little Havana, thousands of protesters have gathered in the last two weeks, waving red, white and blue flags — Cuban and American — in the pouring rain and the suffocating humidity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Transformer Perfect for a Picnic
description: Food52’s helpful carrier can quickly become a small table for entertaining.
content: Flip this compact plain wood carrier for food, drinks and utensils and it becomes a low table for serving or eating poolside, on a beach blanket or on a coverlet in the grass. The sides and legs fold up to turn it into a carrier, which is easily opened and locked to transition from accessory to furniture. It has great house gift potential.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: State’s Rent Relief Program Is Off to a Slow Start
description: Housing groups say technical glitches have hobbled the website, and tenants have encountered errors that  wiped away entire applications.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Macaroon Crossed With a Mounds Bar
description: These hybrid treats with white, milk and dark Belgian chocolate are filled with a variety of flavors.
content: Take the typical chocolate-covered coconut macaroon, a Passover treat, and cross it with a venerable Mounds bar and you have this hybrid, called Maccs. A New York entrepreneur, Michelle A. Goldberg, developed and refined them just before the pandemic hit. Robed in white, milk and dark Belgian chocolate, the bite-size pieces feature fillings like orange zest, espresso, salted caramel, peanut butter and Amarena cherry. They come in packs of four ($10) or a dozen ($26) in a single flavor, as assortments or as custom mixtures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Floods, heat, then floods again: England is battered by wild weather.
description: For the second time in a matter of two weeks, heavy rainfall has wreaked havoc across London, flooding train stations, stranding motorists and forcing at least two hospitals to redirect patients from their emergency rooms.
content: For the second time in a matter of two weeks, heavy rainfall has wreaked havoc across London, flooding train stations, stranding motorists and forcing at least two hospitals to redirect patients from their emergency rooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Devastated by Disasters, Lake Charles Is Still Waiting for Help
description: The Louisiana city, hobbled by two hurricanes, a winter storm and a flood, has struggled to translate sympathy into financial support. It is a challenge other cities could soon face.
content: LAKE CHARLES, La. — Nic Hunter, the mayor of Lake Charles, has no doubt that elected officials in Washington are well aware of everything his city has weathered. They have told him so, repeatedly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Medical groups call for mandatory vaccination of U.S. health care workers.
description: Vaccination “is the logical fulfillment of the ethical commitment of all health care workers,” nearly 60 organizations said in a joint statement.
content: A group of nearly 60 major medical organizations, including the American Medical Association and the American Nurses Association, called on Monday for mandatory vaccination of health care workers. As the highly contagious Delta variant drives a new surge of coronavirus cases, vaccination is an ethical obligation for health care workers, the groups said in a joint statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: This ‘Shazam’ for Birds Could Help Save Them
description: The new Merlin Bird ID app allows users to identify birds by their song, and it has the potential to raise appreciation for our endangered avian friends.
content: NASHVILLE — I spent my entire childhood playing in the woods and meadows of rural Alabama. The world back then was lush and green: cooled by creeks, carpeted by pine needles, attended by birdsong. In those days there were nearly three billion more birds in North America than there are today, and my young days played out beneath the sound of their music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Eric Schmitt
title: Biden Takes Two Paths to Wind Down Iraq and Afghan Wars
description: The differences in how President Biden has handled the wars offer insight not only into America’s strategic interests, but also in how he views the two conflicts.
content: WASHINGTON — When it comes to winding down America’s wars, the contrast between President Biden’s handling of Iraq and Afghanistan is growing sharper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Who is Ariarne Titmus, the Australian nicknamed the Terminator who beat Katie Ledecky?
description: The 20-year-old Australian swimmer called her victory in the women’s 400-meter freestyle “surreal.”
content: Ariarne Titmus of Australia won gold in the women’s 400-meter freestyle on Monday, beating defending champion and world-record holder Katie Ledecky from the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Fitzsimmons, Sharon Otterman, Luis Ferré-Sadurní, Shawn Hubler, Daniel E. Slotnik and Dan Levin
title: New York City and California will require workers to be vaccinated or face testing.
description: The Department of Veterans Affairs on Monday also became the first federal agency to mandate that some of its employees get inoculated.
content: The drive to get Americans vaccinated accelerated on Monday when the most populous state and largest city in the United States announced that they would require their employees to get vaccinated against the coronavirus, or face frequent tests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Hoenicke Flores
title: Doulas Hope to Regain Momentum as Covid Restrictions Ease
description: Monday: Lawmakers were working to address maternal health disparities by expanding access to doula care. Then the pandemic struck.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Russia edged out Japan for the men’s gymnastics team gold.
description: The Russians defeated the 2016 Olympic champions by just over a tenth of a point.
content: TOKYO — The thud of Daiki Hashimoto’s dismount echoed through Ariake Gymnastics Center after a long night of the Olympic gymnastics men’s team final.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: V.A. Issues Vaccine Mandate for Health Care Workers, a First for a Federal Agency
description: Employees who provide direct patient care have eight weeks to get inoculated against the coronavirus or face penalties including possible removal.
content: WASHINGTON — The Department of Veterans Affairs will require 115,000 of its frontline health care workers to be vaccinated against the coronavirus in the next two months, making it the first federal agency to mandate that employees be inoculated, government officials said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Deported Veterans Long to Return From Exile. Some Will Get the Chance.
description: Removed to countries they barely knew after serving time for their crimes, the veterans hope to finally return. “Everything that I am is American.”
content: ROSARITO, Mexico — Alex Murillo leads a full life in the Mexican town of Rosarito, a 40-minute drive from the U.S. border near Tijuana. By day, he works at a call center, speaking in a cheerful, caring tone to retirees across the United States about their Medicare insurance. After work, he crams cleats, flags and other gear into a duffel bag and heads out to coach a youth football team whose players credit him with building their skills in the American sport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Maggie MacNeil of Canada wins the women’s 100-meter butterfly.
description: Results from the women’s 100-meter butterfly at the Tokyo Olympics.
content: Margaret MacNeil of Canada won the 100-meter butterfly in an upset, swimming 55.59 to beat Yufei Zhang of China and Emma McKeon of Australia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: Homeless People Are Moved From Midtown Hotels Back to Shelters
description: Many homeless people who had been living in New York City hotels were frustrated and confused as they were loaded onto buses and taken to group shelters.
content: New York City resumed the process of transferring thousands of homeless people from pandemic hotel rooms back to barracks-style group shelters on Monday, two weeks after a judge halted the moves on the grounds that the city was not giving adequate consideration to people’s health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Tunisia’s democracy verges on dissolution.
content: President Kais Saied late on Sunday said he was firing the prime minister, suspending Parliament and taking control of the country after large anti-government protests over deepening health and economic crises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Luka Doncic of the Mavericks scores 48 as Slovenia routs Argentina.
description: Doncic’s scoring binge tied him for the second most points in a game at the Olympics.
content: SAITAMA, Japan — Luka Doncic made his Olympic debut for Slovenia on Monday. He also made sure it was memorable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Kevin Draper
title: Eyeing the SEC, Oklahoma and Texas Plan to Leave the Big 12
description: The Longhorns and the Sooners may move to the Southeastern Conference, which could soon have 16 teams. The repercussions would be felt across college sports.
content: Starting what would be the most consequential reordering of college sports conferences in about a decade, the University of Oklahoma and the University of Texas told the Big 12 on Monday that they would leave the league in the coming years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Tunisia’s Democracy Verges on Collapse as President Moves to Take Control
description: The effort by President Kais Saied threatened the only democracy to emerge from the Arab Spring protests a decade ago, and his opponents called it a coup.
content: CAIRO — Tunisia’s fledgling democracy, the only one remaining from the popular revolutions that swept the Arab world a decade ago, trembled on the brink of collapse Monday after its president sought to seize power from the rest of the government in what his political opponents denounced as a coup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib
title: Mexican Workers on Border Get Vaccines to Aid Them, and the U.S. Economy
description: Workers in factories that produce goods for the U.S. are getting American vaccines. Officials in both countries hope the program will help reopen the border and restore their economies.
content: TIJUANA — They labor in factories in Mexico producing goods U.S. consumers enjoy. But where American communities are awash in unused coronavirus vaccines, Mexican workers are often hard-pressed to find a single shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: In Iraq, Going Viral Can Bring Fame, and the Threat of Violence
description: Ali Adil reached out to President Biden in video from his hot, dusty rooftop. The video brought millions of likes. It also left him afraid to leave his house.
content: HILLA, Iraq — When Ali Adil, upset over another electricity outage during a sweltering summer, stomped up the stairs to the roof of his family’s home and recorded a video appealing to President Biden for help, the teenager did not expect a response.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Is Jeff Bezos Really an Astronaut?
description: Blue Origin pinned custom astronaut wings to his flight suit. The Federal Aviation Administration may disagree. Or it may not even matter.
content: Say you’re Jeff Bezos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: The Skateboarders Taking Over Are Among the Youngest Olympians in Tokyo
description: The presence of several teenagers in skateboarding, especially among women, is helping the sport’s Olympic goal of getting more youth into the Games.
content: TOKYO — Youth was served to a global audience on Monday when two 13-year-old skateboarders fought to the final trick to determine the winner of the women’s street competition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly and Lananh Nguyen
title: Rookie Bankers Sour on Wall Street’s Pitch of Big Pay and Long Hours
description: As young professionals re-examine their work-life balance, investment banking is becoming a less popular choice despite the money.
content: When Vince Iyoriobhe joined Bank of America’s investment banking division as a rookie analyst in 2017, he planned to stick around just long enough to get the experience needed to pursue his dream career in another corner of finance entirely — private equity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: A voting rights group backed by athletes launches a campaign focused on criminal justice reform.
description: The campaign, called Protect Our People, kicked off Monday with an episode of the HBO series “The Shop,” which is produced by LeBron James and his friend and business partner, Maverick Carter.
content: More Than a Vote, the organization launched a year ago by prominent Black athletes and entertainers to protect African Americans’ voting rights, is launching a campaign focused on the nation’s criminal justice system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers, Keith Bradsher and Chris Buckley
title: As China Boomed, It Didn’t Take Climate Change Into Account. Now It Must.
description: China’s breathtaking economic growth created cities ill-equipped to face extreme weather. Last week’s dramatic floods showed that much will have to change.
content: China’s breakneck growth over the last four decades erected soaring cities where there had been hamlets and farmland. The cities lured factories, and the factories lured workers. The boom lifted hundreds of millions of people out of the poverty and rural hardship they once faced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Weight lifter Hidilyn Diaz makes history, securing the first Olympic gold for the Philippines.
description: Diaz broke the country’s nearly century-long drought by capturing the women’s 55 kilogram division while setting two Olympic records.
content: TOKYO — Until Monday, the Philippines, a sports-mad country of nearly 110 million people, had never won an Olympic gold medal.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: U.S. Swimmers Go From Zero Medals to Six
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 26, 2021.
content: “This is my lifelong dream. I’ve accomplished everything else in the sport — world titles, N.C.A.A. titles, an American record — and this was the last thing I wanted to check off.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Ending Bitter 3-Month Standoff, Samoa’s Leader Concedes Election Defeat
description: Fiame Naomi Mata’afa is scheduled to take office as the Pacific Island nation’s first female prime minister.
content: A three-month constitutional crisis that had convulsed the Pacific Island nation of Samoa ended on Monday as its long-serving leader finally conceded an election defeat, making way for the first female prime minister in the country’s 56-year history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Pop Smoke’s Second Posthumous Album, ‘Faith,’ Hits No. 1
description: The new release by the Brooklyn rapper, who was shot and killed last year, tops Billboard, but fell short of his studio debut.
content: “Faith,” the second album by the Brooklyn rapper Pop Smoke to be released since he was shot and killed in February 2020 at the age of 20, tops the Billboard chart this week, just as the previous one did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: You Won’t Believe How This Beetle Walks on Water
description: Scientists observed a beetle walking upside-down on the undersurface of a pool of water.
content: After dark, the Watagan Mountains in New South Wales, Australia, can appear otherworldly to anyone with a headlamp. But things turned stranger than usual in 2015 when John Gould, a behavioral ecologist at the University of Newcastle in Australia, was surveying sandpaper frogs in the forests’ ephemeral pools for his dissertation.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Scenes from the Bootleg Fire, America’s largest blaze.
description: The Bootleg Fire has burned more than 400,000 acres across central Oregon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Adam Peaty of Britain maintains his ownership of the 100-meter breaststroke.
description: Results from the men’s 100-meter breaststroke.
content: Adam Peaty of Britain is one of the handful of athletes at the Tokyo Games who was showing up here to pick up his gold medal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Inflation Has Arrived, but Washington Isn’t Racing to Limit Price Pops
description: Policymakers, now more attuned to the costs of choking off growth early, are sticking by a patient approach as prices rise.
content: Inflation has long been the boogeyman haunting the nightmares of economic policymakers from both parties — and controlling it has been a top economic priority. But as the economy reopens from pandemic shutdowns and prices spike, it is becoming clear just how much that conventional wisdom has shifted in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Jill Biden, Changing the Fashion Game
description: Cheering the American Olympians, the first lady broke with recent sartorial customs.
content: The game of first lady fashion is one played 12 months a year, at pretty much any time, watched by a global mass of avid spectators who care for reasons national, personal and political. Participants are drafted as soon as they get their jobs, whether they like it or not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Hollywood Head Spinner: Universal Spends Big for New ‘Exorcist’ Trilogy
description: The deal, expected to be announced this week, is for more than $400 million and is a direct response to the streaming giants that are upending the film industry’s economics.
content: LOS ANGELES — Heads are spinning in Hollywood: Universal Pictures and its streaming-service cousin have closed a $400 million-plus megadeal to buy a new “Exorcist” trilogy, signaling a sudden willingness to compete head-on with the technology giants that are upending entertainment industry economics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Inyoung Kang
title: U.S. broadcast coverage on Monday morning includes diving, cycling and 3x3 basketball.
description: Here are some highlights of U.S. broadcast coverage for early Monday morning, including diving and three-on-three basketball. All times are Eastern.
content: Here are some highlights of U.S. broadcast coverage for early Monday morning, including diving and three-on-three basketball. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: China moves against private tutoring companies, causing shares to plunge.
description: Beijing’s latest regulatory move in the tech sector requires online tutoring firms to become nonprofit institutions.
content: Chinese regulators barred tutoring companies from making profits, a move that sent their shares plummeting on Monday, erasing tens of billions of dollars from the value of the country’s once blistering education sector, as Beijing turns its focus to the growing financial burden that students — and their parents — face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Floods, Heat, Then Floods Again: England Is Battered by Wild Weather
description: Thunderstorms in London flooded hospitals’ emergency rooms and submerged streets for the second time this month.
content: LONDON — For the second time in a matter of two weeks, heavy rainfall has wreaked havoc across London, flooding train stations, stranding motorists and forcing at least two hospitals to redirect patients from their emergency rooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad and David E. Sanger
title: A 2nd New Nuclear Missile Base for China, and Many Questions About Strategy
description: Is China scrapping its “minimum deterrent” strategy and joining an arms race? Or is it looking to create a negotiating card, in case it is drawn into arms control negotiations?
content: In the barren desert 1,200 miles west of Beijing, the Chinese government is digging a new field of what appears to be 110 silos for launching nuclear missiles. It is the second such field discovered by analysts studying commercial satellite images in recent weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: ‘It’s a Tough Time to Be Mayor’: Lori Lightfoot Responds to Her Critics
description: The mayor of Chicago talks about the city’s Covid response, why she doesn’t support the defund-the-police movement and her controversial efforts to improve newsroom diversity.
content: Mayors across the country are facing heat. Bill DeBlasio was New York’s default punching bag (perhaps deservedly) throughout the pandemic. Keisha Lance Bottoms decided to forgo seeking a second term as the mayor of Atlanta. And in Chicago, Lori Lightfoot faces critics at every turn. Lightfoot, who in describing herself says, “Roll it all up — I’m Black, I’m female, I’m a lesbian, and no one expected me to win,” is two years into a term that has been defined by a brutal pandemic, a deeply unequal economy and rising crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Taking Back Appalachian Forests, One Bee at a Time
description: The Appalachian Beekeeping Collective sells honey and works to revive forests left scarred and abandoned by mines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: A Common Heart Problem That’s Easy to Miss
description: About three million adults in the U.S. have been diagnosed with A-fib, a heart-rhythm abnormality that’s on the rise. Here’s how to recognize the signs and treat it.
content: Ned Hallick, a lighting specialist accustomed to hauling heavy equipment, was 63 when he first noticed occasional spells of lightheadedness. Then one day, Mr. Hallick, who lives in Brooklyn, told me, “I became so exhausted that walking up the subway stairs felt like I was climbing a mountain.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Steven Lee Myers
title: Biden’s China Strategy Meets Resistance at the Negotiating Table
description: Washington hopes to find areas of collaboration, while also confronting Beijing on disputed issues. But talks between the two sides began with harsh words from Chinese officials.
content: As it seeks to manage an increasingly testy relationship, the Biden administration has mapped out a strategy of confronting China on points of dispute, while leaving the door open for cooperation against global threats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Picnic Boxes That Support Refugees
description: The price of meals from Eat Offbeat, which employs mainly refugee cooks, include a donation to the Refugee and Immigrant Center for Education and Legal Services.
content: Eat Offbeat, an organization that employs mainly refugee cooks for catering, is now offering a couple of picnic boxes: one with Syrian food and the other, vegan, with a mix of items from the Middle East and Asia. The kits, which come in a cooler bag, include ingredients for stuffing pita pockets with chicken or cauliflower shawarma and toppings, a fattoush or mango salad, dips and spreads with pita chips and drinks. The picnics serve six to eight for $84, including delivery in the five boroughs and a 10 percent donation to Raices, the Refugee and Immigrant Center for Education and Legal Services. Additional items like snacks and desserts are also sold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter and Taimoor Shah
title: Afghan Civilian Casualties Soar as U.S. Exits, Monitors Say
description: Detentions and summary executions of those accused of colluding with the Kabul government were also reported, with the Taliban found to be largely responsible.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Civilian casualties and rights violations are rising sharply in Afghanistan, human rights groups say, with the Taliban carrying out the bulk of the offenses as they wage a campaign against the government amid the void left by departing American forces.
source.name: The New York Times

description: California’s largest wildfire this year, the Dixie Fire, started more than a week ago and has burned approximately 200,000 acres, according to state officials.

title: Great Zukes!
description: You have all the summer squash, and we have loads of recipes.
content: Good morning. We’re not quite at the point where people are locking their cars to keep neighbors from loading the front seats down with their surplus zucchini. But there’s a fair amount of squash out there right now, and we’re cooking our fair share.
